title: 110_s1582
content: The Act may be cited as the "Hydrographic Services Improvement Act Amendments of 2008". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 (33 U.S.C. 892) is amended to define hydrographic data as information acquired through various surveying methods and used in providing hydrographic services. Hydrographic data includes geodetic, geospatial, geomagnetic measurements, tide, water level, and current observations, used in providing hydrographic services such as managing, maintaining, interpreting, certifying, and disseminating bathymetric, shoreline, and nautical information. The curr_chunk discusses the production of nautical charts, databases, and other products derived from hydrographic data, as well as the development of nautical information systems and related activities under the Coast and Geodetic Survey Act of 1947. The functions of the Administrator are outlined in Section 3. Section 303 of the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 (33 U.S.C. 892a) is amended to promote safe, efficient, and environmentally sound marine transportation by providing hydrographic services and fulfilling the duties of the Administration under the Coast and Geodetic Survey Act. The Administrator is authorized to procure, lease, evaluate, test, develop, and operate vessels, equipment, and technologies to ensure safe navigation and maintain expertise in hydrographic data acquisition and services under the Coast and Geodetic Survey Act. The Administrator is authorized to procure, lease, evaluate, test, develop, and operate vessels, equipment, and technologies necessary for safe navigation and expertise in hydrographic data acquisition and services. Additionally, they may design, install, maintain, and operate real-time hydrographic monitoring systems to enhance navigation safety and efficiency. They may also acquire hydrographic data to support conservation and management of coastal and ocean resources. The Administrator may acquire hydrographic data and provide services to support safe navigation, conservation of coastal resources, and emergency response efforts for saving lives and protecting property. The Administrator has the authority to acquire hydrographic data and establish joint centers with other entities to fulfill the purposes of the Act. They are also required to award contracts for hydrographic data acquisition in accordance with specific regulations. SEC. 4. HYDROGRAPHIC SERVICES REVIEW PANEL. The Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 is amended to specify the composition of the panel, consisting of 15 voting members appointed by the Administrator, with nonvoting members including the Co-directors of the Center for Coastal and Ocean Mapping/Joint Hydrographic Center and up to 2 NOAA employees. Voting members must be experts in hydrographic data and related fields. The voting members of the panel must be experts in disciplines related to hydrographic data, marine transportation, port administration, vessel pilotage, coastal and fishery management, as determined appropriate by the Administrator. Section 306 of the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 (33 U.S.C. 892d) is amended to authorize appropriations. The Administrator is authorized appropriations for nautical mapping and charting functions, excluding hydrographic surveys, with specific amounts allocated for fiscal years 2009 to 2012. Additionally, funds are designated for contracting hydrographic surveys, including vessel leasing or time chartering, with specified amounts for fiscal years 2009 to 2011. The Administrator is authorized appropriations for hydrographic surveys, vessel operations, and geodetic functions with specific amounts allocated for fiscal years 2009 to 2012. The Administrator is authorized appropriations for hydrographic surveys, vessel operations, geodetic functions, and tide and current measurement functions with specific amounts allocated for fiscal years 2009 to 2012. The Administrator is authorized appropriations for hydrographic surveys, vessel operations, geodetic functions, tide and current measurement functions with specific amounts allocated for fiscal years 2009 to 2012, including $27,000,000 for 2009, $27,500,000 for 2010, $28,000,000 for 2011, $28,500,000 for 2012, and $75,000,000 for acquiring a replacement hydrographic survey vessel. SEC. 6. Authorized NOAA Corps strength is amended to specify the number of authorized commissioned officers. Effective October 1, 2009, the total number of authorized commissioned officers in the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's commissioned corps will increase from 321 to 379, subject to certain conditions such as submission of ship recapitalization and aircraft remodernization plans, availability of funding, and justification of organizational needs.
